DOC.HEAD: Washington Post, San Francisco Examiner Win Contest
Eds: SUBS grafs 6-8, `Certificates of ..., to CORRECT spelling of Laurie, sted Lori, and Staats, sted Stalts.
DOC.TEXT: Reporter Ken Ringle of The Washington Post won the top award for best story and the San Francisco Examiner won for the best series in the annual J.C. Penney-University of Missouri Newspaper Awards. Ringle won the Paul Myhre Award for Excellence in Reporting for a story titled ``Memory and Anger.'' The Examiner staff won the Myhre award for a series called ``Gay in America.'' About 1,600 entries were received from 237 newspapers for the 30th annual judging. The winners were announced this week by Dean Mills, dean of the Missouri School of Journalism. The awards are to be presented April 4 at the end of the annual J.C. Penney-Missouri Newspaper Workshop. Joe Bargmann of the Boston Phoenix and Clifford Pugh of The Houston Post were awarded certificates of merit in the Myhre category for single stories. Certificates of merit also went to Pete Hernon of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Laurie Garrett of Newsday in New York and Long Island, Paul McEnroe of the Star Tribune in Minneapolis, Minn., Marco R. della Cava of the El Paso (Texas) Times, Bob Welch of the Journal American in Bellevue, Wash., and Donald Patterson of the Greensboro (N.C.) News & Record. Steve Sonsky of The Miami Herald took the top prize in the Arts and Entertainment category for ``Bye Pal.'' Certificates of merit went to James Chute of The Orange County (Calif.) Register, Matty Karas of the Asbury Park (N.J.) Press, Deloris Tarzen Ament of The Seattle Times, Rick Morin of The Washington Times, and Lynn Rollings of the Alabama Journal in Montgomery. Craig Staats of The Tribune in Oakland, Calif., was the winner in the Consumer Affairs category. Certificates of merit were giving to Anne Voegetlin of The Columbian in Vancouver, Wash., and to the features staff of The Miami Herald. The judges did not award a top prize in the fashion category, saying ``we need fashion writers to tell us not just what style is popular, but why.'' Marina Pisano of the San Antonio Express-News and Glenn Kessler of Newsday were given honorable mentions for fashion writing. In Food and Nutrition, Sheryl Julian of The Boston Globe won for ``Getting Food to the Hungry.'' Steve Sternberg of the Atlanta Journal won in Health and Fitness. Certificates of merit went to Tom Harris of The Sacramento Bee and Diana Hunt of the Houston Chronicle. Awards were also made for Lifestyle sections. The winners were the Jackson Hole (Wyo.) Guide and the Mercer Island (Wash.) Reporter in circulation 10,000 and under; the Brazosport (Texas) Facts, the Visalia (Calif.) Times Delta and The Reporter in Marin, Calif., in circulation 10,000 to 25,000; the Gwinett (Ga.) Daily News, the Marin (Calif.) Independent Journal and the St. Cloud (Minn.) Times in circulation 25,000 to 50,000; the Syracuse (N.Y.) Herald Journal and The Register Guard in Eugene, Ore., in circulation 50,000 to 100,000; The Washington Times, the Albuquerque (N.M.) Journal and the Virginian-Pilot in Norfolk, Va., in circulation 100,000 to 200,000; and The Miami Herald, the San Jose (Calif.) Mercury News and the Star Tribune in Minneapolis, Minn., in circulation over 200,000.
